title: Screen-Reader Add-Ons for Firefox
content:
Hello Lovely Firefox Volunteers,

I hope this email finds you well. I am a long-time user and fan of Firefox, and other open source projects. Firefox is a fantastic internet browser!

Having said that, I was shocked and dismayed at what I encountered today. I was doing some tests for screen-reader usability on a website, and I came across the following:

Image 1 (attached): Advertisement of Screen-Reader Add-Ons for Firefox

Image 2 (attached): No Screen-Reader Add-Ons for Firefox are Available

The Firefox team is advertising screen-reader add-ons for Firefox, which don't seem to exist. I don't think the recommendation here should be: take down the advertisement for the Firefox native screen-reader add-ons/link to them, these seem to be really important for accessibility, and the Firefox team seems to acknowledge this. :)

There is some other missing piece - maybe there are Screen-reader add-ons for Firefox, and they aren't being linked to? Maybe the wrong tag is being used? (The auto tag that is used in the link is "screen reader"). Maybe there aren't any, and this is an area that needs some additional attention?

Anyway, I just thought I should bring this to your attention as making our internet accessible to people living with blindness and loss of sight is extremely important.

Sincerely, Katie
creator: kmcmi046

title: Disable "interventions" (Flippy?) FF 102.1ESR
content:
Just jumped from 91ESR to 102ESR, and am annoyed by some new "features". (That's why I use ESR, so this doesn't happen often.)

First, I noticed that the default for downloading changed from "ask" to "save". I eventually found how to fix that, but, in the process of searching, I typed "firefox download" in the urlbar, and suddenly up popped "Trying to fix a problem?", suggesting I reset Firefox.

I'm old enough to remember Clippy (look it up), and feel the same way as I did then. Call this new feature "Flippy".

I did some searches, found that this behavior has been called "intervention" (I prefer "Flippy"). I also found old sugesstions on how to disable it, but they don't seem to work.

Even Microsoft provided a way of disabling Clippy. How do I disable "Flippy"?

title: Default Home Page Will Change Upon Closing and Reopening of Firefox
content:
Hello, 

    I bought a p.c. from Originpc.com back in 2020 and it had an option to have firefox preinstalled on the computer. Being a lazy person such as myself and thinking I would save the headache of having to install it through Microsoft Edge, I opted into having it installed. Upon booting up my computer and opening firefox, I realized that the homepage was set to originpc.com. I figured that wasn't super weird, but I changed it to google.com because I didn't want that website to be my default homepage. It worked when closing out the program from using the main exit button (the one found in the top right corner), however each time I close all of the individual windows I have open in firefox originpc.com is forced back into the default home page once I relaunch the program. For the past two years I've used an adblocker as a lazy-man's solution to this problem, however now instead of a "this website blocked" screen, I'm back at originpc.com. I have tried uninstalling and reinstalling the program, I have tried wiping my default settings for firefox multiple times, I have tried googling answers left and right but I have not found any semblance of a solution to this problem. I can't find anything in my computer's firefox files that has anything to do with Originpc. Is there anything that I can do? Or perhaps something that I am missing? Thank you for your time.
creator: th3n1ghthawk39
